reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 7. Trade and Investment Policy

description.narrative: In terms of generic ECDPM impact pursued, the changes pursued are sustainable economic transformation in Africa with shared prosperity and decent jobs, supported by effective international cooperation frameworks and tools (in this case related to trade and investment) for tackling African and global challenges. Such an overall change will need to build on other specific changes which ECDPM will seek to contribute to, including:Development and implementation of EU-Africa/ACP/Africa trade and investment policies and agreements (e.g. economic partnership agreements - EPAs) to promote sustainability and economic transformation in a coherent manner supportive of the SDGs, and with a greater private sector and inclusive focusA more coherent EU trade policy, including in the pursuit of non-trade policy objectives, relative to standards, values, sustainability and development, articulating its soft power in the trade policy arena in a responsible and conducive manner for sustainable development

Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2018-01-01 - 2019-01-27

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

description.narrative: Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

Trade and Investment Policy 1. Context and outcome areas Conducive trade and investment policies are critical factors towards sustainable economic transformation in Africa with shared prosperity and decent jobs. The aim of ECDPM work is to inform and promote the development and implementation by Europe and African states (and regions) of such trade and investment frameworks. Debate on what is an appropriate trade and investment agenda is largely polarised. What trade policies are called for, and what support measures are needed to facilitate progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)? One of the challenges for public actors is to find ways for more effectively stimulating inclusive trade and productive investments for sustainable development. These mechanisms will have to include the poorest and most vulnerable countries. In this respect, it is key to understand the factors and driving forces behind policy initiatives and their implementation. A major challenge is to develop coherent approaches and build on synergies, including for sustainable international value chains and to link trade with investment agendas. Of particular bearing for Africa are the endeavours towards the establishment of the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) as well as the implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) in the context of regional integration dynamics. In Europe, implementation of the he EU’s ‘Trade for All’ Strategy and the External Investment Plan (EIP) help redefine EU interventions. Developments surrounding Brexit will also affect the UK and Europe’s trade and investment relationships with Africa and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. 2. ECDPM contributions made to the main changes envisaged 2.1. Development and implementation of EU-Africa/ACP/Africa trade and investment policies and agreements (e.g. economic partnership agreements - EPAs) to promote sustainable economic transformation in a coherent manner supportive of the SDGs, and with a greater private sector and inclusive focus Sustainability dimensions have moved up on the EU trade policy agenda, an endeavour to which ECDPM has actively contributed, including on EPAs and on the revision of the trade and sustainable development (TSD) chapters of EU free trade agreements. ECDPM has influenced the debate by engaging directly with DG Trade, conducting training for European Commission and EU Delegations officials, and contributing to public debates, including events by foundations, civil society and business associations. ECDPM has also been working on a better understanding of the potential Impact of Economic Partnership Agreements on the development of African value chains, spelling out the principles and opportunities under the EPAs, as well as constraints, to foster sustainable value chains development. We conducted an analysis focusing on examples (Kenya dairy, Namibia fisheries and horticulture) as illustrative insights on EPA potentials. This contributed to influence the approach of Germany (and its main development agency, GIZ, in particular) to support EPA implementation, and also the EU approach focused along value chains. But the analysis also illustrated the limits of such approaches, which has been picked up by several civil society and knowledge institutions. This activity is also part of a broader ECDPM stream of work on value chains, such as promoting market access for Beninese value chain actors to Nigerian markets, and on the role of trade policy as an enabler, and not an end in itself, as in the work with the UN Food and Agricultural Organisation on Policy coherence for agricultural transformation in African LDCs: Aligning agriculture and trade policymaking processes ECDPM has also actively participated to the Joint Consultative Committee of the EU-CARIFORUM EPA, helping to shape its approach, priorities and activities; this JCC has however only limited impact, which we try to increase by our involvement in the process. We do so also by contributing to the discussion (within the European Commission, with experts/academic research group, with civil society and public debate) on the roles and effectiveness of the Consultative Committee and Domestic Advisory Group in EU free trade agreements. In order to help shape trade policies that better respond to domestic interests, we are also engaged in political economy analyses of trade in Africa. In close cooperation with FAO and the Southern African Development Community (SADC), we conducted an analysis on "Understanding the SADC trade and transport agendas" aimed at identifying the key factors and actors affecting SADC’s trade and transport agendas and the implementation of these agendas, to impact not only SADC, but also the Tripartite Free Trade Agreement, paving the way to the African Continental Free Trade Area. And we engaged with South African and Nigerian stakeholders on this continental trade framework to help shed light on the domestic interest dynamics of these two major countries whose interests will shape not only the outcome of the AfCFTA negotiations, but also the implementation process (which might be derailed if not based on sufficient strong domestic impetus). ECDPM has also started a 3-year EC funded Horizon 2020 project with European top universities and think tanks on “Realizing Europe’s Soft Power in External Cooperation and Trade” (RESPECT), which focuses on the design and effectiveness of EU external policies, particularly trade and development policies (including development cooperation and aid for trade), the coherence of Member State activities on the trade and development front (including trade promotion and economic diplomacy) with what the EU institutions do/are mandated to do, and assessments of EU participation in and use of multilateral mechanisms, including G20 and the World Trade Organisation, with a view to Developing practical and operationally feasible recommendations to promote better EU external policy objectives. Last, our work has also contributed to improve the understanding of the possible trade implications of Brexit for developing countries, and Africa in particular, through specific analyses, articles, events and social media. 3. Did you consider gender issues during the process of engagement? ECDPM has focused on ways to mainstream gender in the trade agenda, raising the issue on social media, and stressing the issue in training notably for officials from the European Commission and EU Delegations.
